docs.lead_paragraph: In Their View Among the artists is a Tunisian who began his career by drawing in charcoal on the walls of the bakery where he was an apprentice. There is also a Romanian-born man who swam the Danube as a boy to escape Communism and who became obsessed with painting flying saucers. The creations of these and others like them -- self-taught, intuitive, visionary -- will be on view from tomorrow through Sunday in the 10th anniversary Outsider Art Fair. This event, in the Puck Building in SoHo, brings together more than 1,000 works in all mediums. Ever Popular The songs include standards like ''Blues in the Night,'' ''That Old Devil Moon,'' ''The Lady Is a Tramp,'' ''Cheek to Cheek'' and ''Over the Rainbow.'' Among the songwriters are Johnny Mercer, Harold Arlen, Richard Rodgers, Oscar Hammerstein, Burton Lane, E. Y. Harburg and Irving Berlin, and the lineup of singers is an array of cabaret stars. One night won't hold them all. So the fourth season of Lincoln Center's American Songbook series will continue with three nights of entertainment, beginning with ''An Evening With Margaret Whiting, Hosted by Mary Cleere Haran'' at 8 tomorrow night in the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse in the Rose Building, 165 West 65th Street, between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway. At 8 and 10 on Saturday night, Eric Comstock and Paula West will perform songs by Lane, and at 5 p.m. Sunday, Rob Kapilow will be joined by Ann Hampton Callaway in ''Say It With Music: The Art of the American Song.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The nature of filmmaking and all of American life has changed so completely since midcentury that there will probably never be a figure comparable to Edith Head. No one will ever again design clothes for the stars of more than 1,000 films, be nominated for 35 Academy Awards, win 8 and at the same time shape the look of millions of American women. But although Head died in 1981 at 82, she has made a return of sorts with the opening of a new play called ''Sketches: Edith Head's Hollywood.'' It has a few lines for actors with small roles as fans and a personal assistant, but in essence it is a one-woman show drawn almost exclusively from Head's own words.
docs.abstract: Arts In America column discusses new play Sketches: Edith Head's Hollywood; play is based on career of Edith Head, who designed clothes for Hollywood actors and actresses; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Period Pieces In the United States in the three decades before World War I, vast fortunes were amassed, elegant town houses were built, artists and their patrons traveled abroad. It was, as Mark Twain and Charles Dudley Warner put it, the Gilded Age. Beginning on Saturday, this era will be revisited in an exhibition of 60 masterpieces at the Mint Museum of Art in Charlotte, N.C. On view through April 21, ''The Gilded Age: Treasures From the Smithsonian American Art Museum,'' presents works by artists like Cecilia Beaux, Thomas Eakins, Daniel Chester French, Childe Hassam, Winslow Homer, Albert Pinkham Ryder, Augustus Saint-Gaudens and Louis Comfort Tiffany. Delivering Dante For Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra, great poetry and the music it inspired will intersect in a concert at 8 p.m. Friday in the Lincoln Center Great Performers Series at Avery Fisher Hall. The inspiration is Dante's ''Inferno.'' The program consists of Liszt's ''Symphony on Dante's 'Divine Comedy' '' and a concert performance of Rachmaninoff's one-act opera ''Francesca da Rimini,'' a duet for Dante's lovers Francesca and Paolo describing the second circle of hell.
docs.abstract: Exhibition of Gilded Age masterpieces from Smithsonian American Art Museum is set for Mint Museum of Art, Charlotte, NC; Leon Botstein and American Symphony Orchestra to perform works inspired by Dante's Inferno; photos of art works by students in Grades 7 through 12 that won Scholastic Art Awards and were destroyed in World Trade Center terrorist attack go on display at Scholastic's office; Michael Grandage is named Donmar Warehouse, London, artistic director, succeeding Sam Mendes; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the last 20 years, the use of projected English supertitles has ''given a shot in the arm to opera, for sure,'' the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne said to an audience that filled the Juilliard Theater on Friday night for the ninth annual Marilyn Horne Foundation recital. Since promoting the song recital is the purpose of her foundation, Ms. Horne continued, she decided to try an experiment in the first half of the evening's program and use supertitles to provide simultaneous English translation of the German texts to 18 songs by Mozart, Korngold, Brahms and Strauss. The main goal of the event was to present four promising young singers, all recent winners of foundation awards, who are being sponsored in various recital appearances around the United States. The theme of the program, ''Vienna to Broadway,'' was the influence of 19th-century Viennese song on 20th-century American operetta and musical theater. But Ms. Horne's experiment with supertitles, which has not been tried much in recital format, is likely to generate the most debate.
docs.abstract: Anthony Tommasini Critic's Notebook column on Marilyn Horne Foundation song recital discusses use of supertitles to translate songs; photos (M)

docs.snippet: ''A Beautiful Mind,'' Ron Howard's emotional thriller about a brilliant but schizophrenic mathematician, won the Golden Globe Award for best dramatic motion picture tonight, while ''Moulin Rouge,'' Baz Luhrmann's self-consciously gaudy attempt to ...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''A Beautiful Mind,'' Ron Howard's emotional thriller about a brilliant but schizophrenic mathematician, won the Golden Globe Award for best dramatic motion picture tonight, while ''Moulin Rouge,'' Baz Luhrmann's self-consciously gaudy attempt to resurrect the movie musical, was named best comedy or musical film. Many had hoped that the 59th annual Golden Globe Awards would help clarify what had been a fairly muddled movie awards season, perhaps giving some indication of what films were likely to figure prominently in the Academy Awards in March. Certainly, both ''Moulin Rouge'' and ''A Beautiful Mind'' got significant boosts at tonight's ceremonies, which were held in the International Ballroom of the Beverly Hilton Hotel here.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Sundance Film Festival in the snowy, condo-choked valleys of the Wasatch Range had seen so much of its excitement fade away in recent years that many people approached this 20th gathering as a kind of visit with an invalid. But then, defying expectations, the dark and innovative films that made up much of this year's roster began to create a stir, and suddenly the odor of infirmity drifted away.
docs.abstract: Rick Lyman reports on scene at Sundance Film Festival, Park City, Utah; Robert Redford, festival's founder and guiding spirit, who has been virtually absent in recent years, is present everywhere this year; photos (M)

docs.snippet: Harvey Weinstein, the shrewd and bellicose leader of the Miramax Films empire, had kept a rather low profile at  the Sundance Film Festival the last two years. But last week, he was back in full force at the festival, deftly acquiring several of t...
docs.lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein, the shrewd and bellicose leader of the Miramax Films empire, had kept a rather low profile at the Sundance Film Festival the last two years. But last week, he was back in full force at the festival, deftly acquiring several of the gathering's most eagerly sought movies while promoting Miramax's prospects in the current Oscar race. He had lost focus for a while, Mr. Weinstein said, first when a debilitating illness briefly sidelined him two years ago and then when he placed his energy and competitive instincts into backing Vice President Al Gore and other liberal candidates in the 2000 election.
docs.abstract: Interview with Miramax Films head Harvey Weinstein on his plans to refocus on smaller, independent films; return to roots follows collapse of Miramax's co-publishing venture, Talk magazine; photo (M)
